review.title: Towards Blended Reactive Planning and Acting using Behavior Trees
review.abstract: In this paper, we study the problem of using a planning algorithm to automatically create and update a Behavior Tree (BT), controlling a robot in a dynamic environment. Exploiting the characteristic of BTs, in terms of modularity and reactivity, the robot continually acts and plans to achieve a given goal using a set of abstract actions and conditions. The construction of the BT is based on an extension of the Hybrid Backward-Forward algorithm (HBF) that allows us to refine the acting process by mapping the descriptive models onto operational models of actions, thus integrating the ability of planning in infinite state space of HBF with the continuous modular reactive action execution of BTs. We believe that this might be a first step to address the recently raised open challenge in automated planning: the need of a hierarchical structure and a continuous online planning and acting framework. We prove the convergence of the proposed approach as well as the absence of deadlocks and livelocks, and we illustrate our approach in two different robotics scenarios.

sections.heading: VII. RESULTS
sections.text: In this section, we will show how the proposed approach can be applied to complex problems based on two different scenarios: First, a KUKA Youbot scenario, in which we demonstrate the applicability of our approach to dynamic and unpredictable environments, emphasizing the importance of continuous planning and action; second, an ABB Yumi Industrial Manipulator scenario, in which we highlight the applicability of our approach to real-world plans that require the execution of a long sequence of actions; and second, an ABB Yumi Industrial Manipulator scenario, in which we demonstrate the applicability of our approach to real-world plans that require the execution of a long sequence of actions, performed using the physics simulator V-REP, internal implementations of low-level controllers for actions and conditions, and an open source BT library6. sections.heading: A. KUKA Youbot experiments
sections.text: In these scenarios, which are an extension of Examples 1 and 2, a KUKA Youbot must place a green cube on a goal surface, see Figures 11 and 12. The robot has a single arm with a simple parallel gripper. sections.heading: B. ABB Yumi experiments
sections.text: In these scenarios, an ABB Yumi must assemble a mobile phone whose parts are scattered on a table, see Figure 13. The robot is equipped with two arms with simple parallel grippers that are not suitable for skillful manipulation, and some parts must be held in a specific position. For example, the opening on the chassis of the mobile phone must be turned away from the arm of the robot and released for assembly. However, the starting position of one part may require multiple grips to transfer the part to the other gripper and effectively change its orientation. See video link above.

sections.heading: VIII. CONCLUSIONS
sections.text: In this paper, we have proposed a framework that, to the best of our knowledge, automatically synthesizes a BT that fulfills a goal in the face of a series of abstract nodes of action and condition.The framework combines the advantages of BT in terms of modularity and reactivity with the infinite dimensional planning capability of the HBF algorithm, and the resulting approach is an attempt to address the challenges identified in the planning community in terms of mixing planning and action. We analyzed the framework from a theoretical standpoint and demonstrated its applicability in dynamic and unpredictable scenarios.

sections.heading: IX. FUTURE WORK
sections.text: We study the integration of this type of blended planning and acting with the learning of action templates. In particular, we are interested in learning the prerequisites and effects for each action useful for planning. Recent work [17] shows how BTs are suitable for enhanced learning. However, note that the challenges we face are slightly different from those addressed in [17]. We are not able to define an objective function that is maximized when the prerequisites are met. [17] Roughly speaking, we find a sufficient set of prerequisites for an action for a particular task. We will be interested in finding necessary and sufficient prerequisites for an action for each task. We believe that the modularity of BTs will allow us to learn individual parts of prerequisites and effects to characterize the action templates. The learning process could be monitored by a professional taking inspiration from [33], [34] or by interacting with the environment to characterize the preconditions for action.

We believe that this might be a first step to address the recently raised open challenge in automated planning: the need of a hierarchical structure and a continuous online planning and acting framework. We prove the convergence of the proposed approach as well as the absence of deadlocks and livelocks, and we illustrate our approach with examples from two different robotics domains.
